title: 104_hr3048
content: The Act may be cited as the "Regulatory Flexibility Amendments Act of 1996". Judicial review is addressed in the Act. Section 611 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to allow small entities to petition for judicial review of final rules that were certified to have no significant economic impact or had a final regulatory flexibility analysis prepared within one year of the rule's effective date. The court has jurisdiction to review certification or analysis under section 553. A petition for judicial review must be filed within one year of the final regulatory flexibility analysis being made public for affected small entities. The court has jurisdiction to review certification or analysis under section 553. A petition for judicial review must be filed within one year of the final regulatory flexibility analysis being made public for affected small entities. An entity refers to a small entity adversely affected by the final rule. The court can order the agency to prepare a final regulatory flexibility analysis if the certification was found to be arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or not in accordance with the law. The court may order corrective action if a final regulatory flexibility analysis was prepared without following required procedures. If the agency fails to prepare the required analysis within a specified period, the court can intervene. The court may stay a rule or grant relief to prepare required analysis or take corrective action. The court must consider the rule of prejudicial error when making determinations. In judicial review, a regulatory flexibility analysis for a rule is part of the record. The amendment allows judicial review of impact statements or similar analyses required by law. It applies to final agency rules issued after the Act's enactment. SEC. 3. RULES COMMENTED ON BY SBA CHIEF COUNSEL FOR ADVOCACY. In Section 612 of title 5, United States Code, a new subsection is added requiring agencies to transmit proposed rules and initial regulatory flexibility analysis to the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration before publication. Section 612 of title 5, United States Code mandates agencies to send proposed rules and initial regulatory flexibility analysis to the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration before publication. The Chief Counsel may then provide feedback within 15 days. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy can submit a written statement on the impact of a proposed rule on small entities. If the statement is submitted, the agency must publish it along with their response in the Federal Register when the proposed rule is announced. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy can submit a written statement on the impact of a proposed rule on small entities, which must be published in the Federal Register. Certain entities related to banking, credit unions, and housing enterprises are exempt from specific requirements under this subsection. Section 603(a) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include reference to section 612(d). Congress believes that the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration should be allowed to participate as amicus curiae in court cases reviewing rules.
